title-group.article-title: Vibration suppression of smart nonlinear flexible appendages of a rotating satellite by using hybrid adaptive sliding mode/Lyapunov control

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Shiraz University, Iran
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Science and Research Branch, Islamic Azad University, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Mohammad Eghtesad, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Shiraz University, Shiraz 71348-51154, I.R. Iran Email: eghtesad@shirazu.ac.ir

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this paper, a hybrid adaptive sliding mode/Lyapunov controller is designed for both the rotational maneuver and the vibration control of smart flexible appendages of a satellite moving in a circular orbit. The satellite is considered as a rigid hub and two flexible appendages with attached piezoelectric layers as sensors and actuators. Each appendage is considered as a nonlinear beam undergoing large deflection. These governing equations of motion are obtained using a Lagrange–Rayleigh–Ritz technique and assumed mode method. The dynamic equations of motion are nonlinear and coupled due to the large angle trajectory and appendages large deflection. A through look at the resulting equations shows that the flexible satellite dynamics including the vibrations of the appendages and their rigid maneuver occur in two different time scales. Using the singular perturbation theory, the dynamics of the flexible satellite are divided into two slow and fast subsystems, the former associated with rigid-body maneuver, while the latter is a result of the vibrations of the appendages. Use of this hybrid controller allows us to cope with parameters uncertainty and disturbances of the system. The stability of the hybrid controller is studied by using the Lyapunov approach. Finally, the whole system is modeled and the simulation results show the efficient performance of the proposed hybrid controller.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, the demands for the development, study and control of flexible spacecraft maneuvers and its vibration reduction have increased.

A number of researchers have studied the dynamics and control of flexible spacecraft having space rotational maneuver around their axes. Manabe (2002) designed a controller for flexible spacecraft attitude control. The flexible structure to be controlled was a simple torsional shaft attached to a rigid disk. The disk represented the rigid body of the spacecraft and the flexible shaft represented the flexible appendage. A multibody dynamics formulation for studying the response of large space structures with interconnected flexible bodies was presented by Suleman (2004). Bang et al. (2005) investigated the sliding mode controller design for flexible spacecraft attitude control with performance analysis by simulation work. The spacecraft model was configured as a rigid body with flexible structures attached. Each structure had a mass element at the tip with negligible rotary inertia. Zheng et al. (2005) studied active optimal attitude control of a flexible spacecraft with flywheels. They approximated the nonlinear system as a sequence of linear and time-varying systems. Attitude regulation control for flexible spacecraft was investigated by Erdong and Zhaowei (2010). Jiang et al. (2010) developed a fault-tolerant adaptive backstepping sliding mode control scheme for flexible spacecraft attitude maneuvering. Nagashio et al. (2010) proposed a two-degree-of-freedom controller as a candidate for precise attitude control of a large spacecraft in order to develop a baseline for future controller design technology. Xin and Pan (2011) formulated spacecraft control to approach a tumbling target by a unified optimal control incorporating control of position attitude and flexible motion.

Hu and Liu (2005) proposed a control scheme of feed-forward control based on component synthesis vibration suppression method and feedback control for vibration reduction of flexible spacecraft during maneuver operation. Hu et al. (2008a) investigated the vibration suppression of stabilized flexible spacecraft during attitude maneuver in the presence of bounded model uncertainty and external disturbance. Hu (2008a) considered a flexible spacecraft and used the robust nonlinear variable structure control strategy integrated with input shaping technique for the pitch angle control and elastic vibration suppression under actuator saturation limit. Hu et al. (2008b) integrated the method of command input shaping and the theory of sliding mode output feedback control for vibration reduction of flexible spacecraft during attitude maneuver. Hu (2009a) designed an adaptive backstepping controller for flexible spacecraft attitude maneuver and elastic vibration control which explicitly took into consideration the bounds on angular velocity. Hu (2010a) designed a simple and robust attitude control strategy for flexible spacecraft in the presence of external disturbance and parameter uncertainties. Hu and Xiao (2011) developed a fault-tolerant sliding mode control scheme for flexible spacecraft attitude stabilization in the presence of partial loss of actuator effectiveness and external disturbances.

Some researchers have studied the spatial rotational motion of a satellite while moving on an orbit. Shen et al. (1994) investigated dynamics of spacecraft with a beam-type appendage free to undergo vibrational motions in the orbital plane during a prescribed slow maneuver. Singh and Zhang (2004) designed an adaptive control system for a single-axis rotational maneuver and vibration suppression of an orbiting spacecraft with flexible appendages. For the synthesis of the control law, only the pitch angle was used for feedback. Hui et al. (2006) considered control of entire-formation maneuvering in low-thrust Earth-orbiting spacecraft formation flying (SFF). In this study each spacecraft was modeled as a point mass. Maganti and Singh (2007) designed a simple adaptive control system for one-axis rotational maneuver of an orbiting spacecraft with flexible appendage. They considered a linear approximated model by ignoring the orbiting effects and other nonlinearities. Dong et al. (2009) applied an adaptive fuzzy sliding mode controller for the networked control systems with nonlinear and uncertain parameters during the flexible spacecraft slew maneuver in a circular orbit. They reduced and decomposed dynamic equations of the spacecraft into three single-input subsystems. In these studies, vibration suppression is not directly considered; so, there is no need to use smart materials for stabilization of vibration of the appendages.

Many studies have been conducted when smart materials and piezoelectric layers are used as sensors and actuators for active vibration suppression of spacecraft flexible appendages. Hu and Ma (2005) proposed a new approach to vibration reduction of flexible spacecraft actuated by on–off thrusters, by applying the variable structure control technique to design the control switching strategies for the thrusters firing while using smart materials for active vibration suppression during the attitude maneuvers. They also developed and studied the applicability of the variable structure output feedback control approach to flexible spacecraft for large-angle rotational maneuvers and integrated it with active vibration technique using piezoelectric layers as the actuator and sensor to actively suppress the elastic mode vibrations (Hu and Ma, 2006a, 2006b). A generalized scheme based on sliding mode control and active vibration control technique using piezoceramic layers was proposed for large-angle attitude maneuver control of flexible spacecraft by Hu (2008b). He designed attitude control system and vibration suppression separately using a lower order model. He also used other controllers to control both maneuver and vibration reduction of flexible spacecraft separately (Hu, 2009b, 2009c, 2010b). Azadi et al. (2011) designed a controller for maneuver control of a satellite together with vibration suppression of its smart flexible appendages.
Also few researches have studied space structures with large deflection of appendages (Banerjee, 1993; Banerjee and Singhose, 1995).

By a thorough look at the literature it can be observed that because of the complicated nature of the nonlinear governing equations of motion of a flexible satellite having a large-angle maneuver, usually simplified models have been considered. In this study, nonlinear governing equations of motion of a flexible satellite having orbiting maneuver are derived using a Lagrange–Rayleigh–Ritz method and no simplification has been performed in this derivation. So these equations of motion are very complicated and nonlinear. The satellite is considered as two flexible appendages and a rigid hub. Each appendage is considered as an Euler–Bernoulli beam having large deflection. Using singular perturbation theory the governing equations of motion are divided into two slow and fast subsystems. These separated equations of motion are used only for applying the control law and in simulation runs the coupled equations of motion are used. A hybrid controller consisting of an adaptive sliding mode control and a Lyapunov-based controller using piezoelectric layers has been proposed for the large-angle attitude maneuver control and vibration suppression of a flexible satellite, respectively. This adaptive sliding mode control scheme is robust against parameter uncertainties and external disturbances. At last the simulation results show the effectiveness and performance of the controller.

sec.title: 2. System dynamics
sec.p:
The system model used in this paper is a satellite that contains two flexible appendages undergoing large deflection, the piezoelectric layers attached to appendages, and a rigid body hub (see Figure 1). Each appendage is assumed as a nonlinear cantilever beam. Each pair of piezoelectric layers is attached on opposite sides of the appendages. We consider the satellite motion in a circular orbit with constant angular velocity Ω; it also has a rotational maneuver around its z1-axis with angular speed of ψ·. XYZ is an Earth-centered inertial reference frame such that YZ is the orbit plane. The origins of the coordinate frames xiyizi (i=1,2) are attached to the hub centers, see Figure 1. Figure 1.
Schematic view of the spacecraft and its coordinates.

sec.title: 2.1. Lagrange’s method
sec.p: The equation of motion and boundary conditions of the system may be derived using Lagrange’s method expressed as (Baruh, 1999) (1)ddt(∂T∂ζ·)-∂T∂ζ+∂U∂ζ=Q where U and T are strain energy and kinetic energy of the system, respectively, and Q is the generalized force. Here ζ refers to the vector of generalized coordinates.

sec.title: 2.2. Kinetics energy
sec.p: The kinetic energy of the system consists of three parts: appendages, piezoelectric layers, and hub kinetic energy. In order to derive the appendages kinetic energy, knowledge of the velocity vector is necessary. So let us consider an appendage element, P, with velocity vector vP. It can be shown that vP is as follows: (2)vP=vH+vP/H+ω×rP/H where vH is the hub velocity, vP/H is the relative velocity of element P with respect to the rigid hub, ω is the vector of hub's angular velocity, and rP/H is the relative position vector of the element P. The large lateral deflection of each point of the ith appendage is denoted by wi(x). The parameters vH, vP/H, ω and rP/H are obtained by the following equations: (3)vH=RΩK∧vP/H=w·j∧2ω=ψ·k∧1+ΩI∧rP/H=xi∧2+wj∧2 where (.) denotes d/dt(). Substituting Equation (3) in Equation (2) yields (4)vP=(w·sinψ+ψ·xsinψ-ψ·wcosψ)I∧ +(w·cosψ+ψ·xcosψ+ψ·wsinψ)J∧ +(RΩ+Ωwcosψ-Ωxsinψ)K∧

The kinetic energy of the panels, hub and piezoelectric layers can be obtained as (5)T=Tapp+TH+TPZT=12ρatab∑a=12∫appavP2dx +(12MHR2Ω2+12IHψ·2+12IHΩ2sin2ψ) +12ρptpb∑a=12∑n=1Na∫PZTkvP2dx where b, ta, ρa, tp and ρp are the width, thickness and density of the panel and thickness and density of the piezoelectric layers, respectively, MH is hub's mass, IH is the hub moment of inertia and Na is the number of piezoelectric layers on the ath appendage.

sec.title: 2.3. Potential energy
sec.p: The potential energy of the system consists of two parts, appendages and piezoelectric layers potential energies. For deriving the elastic energy of the appendages, the relationship between displacement field and strain should be obtained. The displacement field of the beam can be written as (Meirovitch, 1997) (6)uax(x,t)=-y∂wa(x,t)∂xa=1,2 where wa(x,t) and uax(x,t) are the displacements in the y direction and longitudinal x direction of the ith appendage in x2y2z2 coordinate frame, respectively. The high-order strain ɛx for the large deflection is (Lai et al., 1999) (7)ɛx=∂uax∂x+12[(∂uax∂x)2+(∂wa∂x)2],a=1,2
By substituting Equation (6) into Equation (7) the following strain relation is obtained: (8)ɛx=-yd2wa(x,t)dx2 +12[(yd2wa(x,t)dx2)2+(dwa(x,t)dx)2],a=1,2
The stress σx in the appendages is as follows (Meirovitch, 1997): (9)σx=-Ey∂2wa(x,t)∂x2,a=1,2

The stress in piezoelectric layers can be expressed as (Fazelzadeh et al., 2010) (10)σxpn=-Epny∂2wpn∂x2-e31nEznn=1…N where the subscript pn represents the nth piezoelectric layer, en is the equivalent piezoelectric coefficient and Ezn=vn/hpn(n=1…N) is the electric field in the nth piezoelectric layer. The first and second terms on the right-hand side of Equation (10) are the stresses due to the mechanical and electrical effects of the piezoelectric layers, respectively.

On the other hand, the potential energy of the panel and piezoelectric layers is (11)Uapp=12∑a=12∫appaE[y2(∂2wa∂x2)2-y3(∂2wa∂x2)3-y(∂2wa∂x2)(∂wa∂x)2+14y4(∂2wa∂x2)4+12y2(∂2wa∂x2)2(∂wa∂x)2+14(∂wa∂x)4]dV (12)UPZT=12∑a=12∑n=1N∫PZTnEp[y2(∂2wpn∂x2)2-y3(∂2wpn∂x2)3 -y(∂2wpn∂x2)(∂wpn∂x)2+14y4(∂2wpn∂x2)4 +12y2(∂2wpn∂x2)2(∂wpn∂x)2+14(∂wpn∂x)4]dV -∑n=1N∫PZTne31Ezn[-y∂2wpn∂x2+12(y∂2wpn∂x2)2 +12(∂wpn∂x)2]dV+12∑n=1N∫PZTnEzndndV where y is the axis perpendicular to the piezoelectric surface, dn is the electric displacement for the nth patch, E is Young's modulus of the panel and Ep is Young's modulus of the piezoelectric layers. The electric displacement is (13)dn=ɛpnvntp wherein ɛpn is the dielectric constant of the piezoelectric material which forms the nth patch. The last term in Equation (12) is the electric energy stored in the piezoelectric material.

sec.title: 2.4. Rayleigh–Ritz formulation
sec.p: In this method, the generalized coordinates are represented by means of a series of trial functions that should satisfy the geometric boundary conditions, multiplied by time-dependent generalized coordinates. To this end, wj can be represented by a series of trial mode shapes, ϕij, satisfying the boundary conditions, of which each is multiplied by a time-dependent generalized coordinate, qij, that is (Meirovitch, 1997), (14)wj(x,t)=∑iϕijqij=(Φj)Tqj j=1,2Φ=[(Φ1)T(Φ2)T]Tq=[(q1)T(q2)T]T where Φj and qj are the vectors of assumed mode shapes and generalized coordinates of the jth appendage, respectively.

sec.title: 2.4. Governing equations
sec.p: By substituting the kinetic and potential energies into Equation (1) the following set of ordinary differential equations is obtained: (20)M(ζ)ζ··+C(ζ,ζ·)ζ·+K(ζ)ζ+KH(ζ)=Qvs=-KPe-1KPeesTq where M is the mass matrix, C is the matrix of Coriolis and centrifugal effects, K is the stiffness matrix, KH is the circulatory matrix, Q is the vector of controller inputs, vs is the voltage of the sensors and ζ is the vector of generalized coordinates and is defined as (21)ζ=[ψqT]Tq=[(q1)T(q2)T]T
The mass matrix and the matrix of Coriolis and centrifugal effects are defined as follows: (22)M=[MψψMψqMqψMqq],C=[CψψCψqCqψCqq]
The elements of the mass matrix are presented in Appendix A.
The C matrix is defined as (Canudas et al., 1997) (23)Cij=∑k=1Ncijkζ·k where (24)cijk=12(∂[M]ij∂ζk+∂[M]ik∂ζj-∂[M]jk∂ζi)
The stiffness matrix is (25)K=[000Kqq] where Kqq is shown in Appendix A, completely.

Since the piezoelectric parameters can be assumed similar for the sensors and actuators, the matrices of the elastic–electric effects of the piezoelectric actuator and sensor layers, KPeea and KPees are the same: (28)KPeeaorKPees=[KPee100KPee2] where 0 is the zero matrix and (29)KPeei=[Kee1iKee2i…KeeNii] herein Keeji is the vector of the jth column of the elastic–electric matrix and is defined as (30)Keeji=e31jtp∫PZTjiy∂2Φi∂x2dv

It should be noted that since the higher-order terms in Equation (8) have very small effects on the electro–elastic property of piezoelectric materials, so for deriving Equation (30) these higher-order terms of Equation (8) have been neglected.

Here KPe is the diagonal capacitance matrix of the piezoelectric patches: (31)KPe=∑n=1N∫PZTnɛpnPnPnTdv=-1μIN×N where the N×1 vector Pn has zero entries except for entry n which is equal to 1/tp and IN×N is the N×N identity matrix. Knowing the fact that the dielectric constant of the piezoelectric material is a very small negative number (Necsulescu, 2001), it can be concluded that μ is a positive number.

sec.title: 3. Hybrid control system design
sec.p: A hybrid control strategy is designed to control the slow and fast subsystems in order to stabilize the whole system. To reach this purpose, a singular perturbation method is used to decouple the system governing equations of motion to two subsystems. In this study, an adaptive sliding mode controller for maneuver attitude control and a Lyapunov-based controller for suppression of vibrations of appendages are designed.

sec.title: 3.1. Decomposition of the equations of motion by the singular perturbation theory
sec.p: Singular perturbations cause a multi-time-scale behavior of dynamic systems characterized by the presence of both slow and fast transients in the system response to external stimuli (Kokotovic et al., 1999). The underlying idea of this method is to decouple the system dynamics into the slow and fast subsystems and a hybrid control design can be used to control each subsystem, separately. The magnitude of the elements of the stiffness matrix Kqq is very large in comparison with the other coefficients in Equation (20) (Canudas et al., 1997; Mirzaee et al., 2010), so the singular perturbation method is intuitively determined by the magnitude of the elements of the stiffness matrix: (32)[Kqq]{q}=km[K¯qq]{q}={z}[K¯qq]{q}=ɛ2{z} where km is a large coefficient of the stiffness matrix, Kqq, and will be chosen as the order of the matrix K¯qq will be similar to the mass matrices, ɛ is the singular perturbation parameter (Kokotovic et al., 1999), and ɛ2=1/km. Also it can be concluded that O(Kpeea)=O(ɛ); therefore, the Kpeea matrix can be written as (Mirzaee et al., 2010) (33)Kpeea=ɛK¯peea

Substituting the new variables into the governing equations of motion, the following set of equations are obtained (34)[ψ··ɛ2K¯qq-1z··]=[HψψHψqHqψHqq]{-[CψψCψqCqψCqq][ψ·ɛ2K¯qq-1z·] -[0z]-[KHψKHq]+[τ-ɛK¯peeava]} where H=M-1. When ɛ→0, the model of the slow subsystem is recovered. In fact, setting ɛ=0 and solving for z in second row of Equation (34) and then substituting it in the first row, the slow time scale equations are obtained as (35)ψ··s=(Hψψ-HψqHqq-1Hqψ)(-Cψψψ·s-KHψ+τs)=Mψψ-1(-Cψψψ·s-KHψ+τs) herein, subscript s indicates that the system is considered in the slow time scale. A fast subsystem, with O(ɛ2) approximation, can be obtained by setting ξ=t/ɛ, introducing zf=z-zs, treating the slow variables as constant in fast time scale (Kokotovic et al., 1999) and considering the terms of O(ɛ2) and higher equal to zero. It can be expressed as (36)d2dξ2zf=-ɛK¯qq(HqψCψqK¯qq-1+HqqCqqK¯qq-1)ddξzf -K¯qqHqqzf-ɛK¯qqHqqK¯peeava
Using Equation (32), Equation (36) can be rewritten as (37)Hqq-1q··f+(Hqq-1HqψCψq+Cqq)q·f+Kqqqf=-Kpeeava where subscript f means the system is in the fast time scale.

sec.title: 3.2. Adaptive sliding mode control for the slow subsystem
sec.p: Let us consider the governing equations of motion of the system, Equation (20). Owing to the system uncertainty, disturbances and parameters variations, the dynamic model of the system can only present an approximation of the real system. For the slow subsystem, Equation (35) in the presence of uncertainty is of the form (Zeinali and Notash, 2010): (38)(M∧ψψ+ΔMψψ)ψ··+(C∧ψψ+ΔCψψ)ψ·+(K∧Hψ+ΔKHψ)+Td=τ where M∧ψψ, C∧ψψ and K∧Hψ are the known and ΔMψψ, ΔCψψ and ΔKHψ are the unknown parts of the matrices Mψψ, Cψψ and KHψ, respectively; and Td is a vector of bounded external disturbances. It is assumed that the system structure property is satisfied and the uncertainties are guaranteed to be in the range space of the inverse matrix Mψψ-1. Hence, the uncertainty relation can be presented as (39)-M∧ψψF~=ΔMψψψ··+ΔCψψψ·+ΔKHψ+Td
Substituting Equation (39) into Equation (38) yields (40)ψ··=M∧ψψ-1(-C∧ψψψ·-K∧Hψ+τ)+F~ where F~ is the vector of parameter uncertainties and external disturbances of the system.

The uncertainty vector F~(ψ,ψ·,ψ··) and its partial derivatives are assumed to be continuous and locally uniformly bounded (Zeinali and Notash, 2010): (41) |F~(ψ,ψ·,ψ··) |≤ρ(ψ,ψ·,ψ··)<∞ where ρ(ψ,ψ·,ψ··) is an unknown upper bound of |F~(ψ,ψ·,ψ··)|; therefore; the uncertainty vector F~(ψ,ψ·,ψ··) has locally bounded rate of change.

The standard form of sliding mode control scheme for this system is discontinuous and has the following form (Zeinali and Notash, 2010) (42)τ(t)=M∧ψψ(ψ··r-Kbsgn(S))+C∧ψψψ·+K∧Hψ where S is the sliding surface and ψ··r is the filtered tracking error and can be defined as (43)ψ··r=ψ··d-2Λe·-Λ2e wherein ψ··d, e=ψ-ψd, e·=ψ·-ψ·d and Λ are the vector of desired acceleration, the vector of errors, the vector of velocity errors and a diagonal positive-definite constant matrix, respectively, ψd is the desired vector of ψ, Kb represents the bounds of uncertainty vector which have to be known a priori, and sgn(S) is the signum function (Slotine and Li, 1991; Elmali and Olgas, 1992; Kim et al., 1998). The control law defined in Equation (42) can be limited due to chattering and unknown bounds of the uncertainties, so that a continuous adaptive term which can be updated recursively in an online procedure to compensate for time-varying uncertainties will replace the term Kbsgn(S). This continuous adaptive sliding mode control that does not need to know the bounds of uncertainties is based on the combination of sliding mode control and systematic Lyapunov design approaches (Zeinali and Notash, 2010).

The tracking control problem can be achieved by keeping the system trajectory on the sliding surface S(t)=0 (Slotine and Li, 1991). The integral type sliding surface can be chosen for the system described in Equation (35) (Zeinali and Notash, 2010): (44)S(t)=(ddtI+Λ)2(∫edt)=e·+2Λe+Λ2∫edt

In this study, the following control law with variable parameters is considered (Zeinali and Notash, 2010) (45)τ(t)=τeq+τPID+τ∧p where τeq, τPID, and τ∧p are the equivalent control term, a PID type controller, and an adaptive controller for perturbation parameters, respectively. The equivalent control term is used for the system without considering the parameter uncertainty and disturbances. We know that S·=0 while the system dynamics is on the sliding mode (Slotine and Li, 1991). By differentiating Equation (44) with respect to time the following equation will be obtained: (46)S·(t)=e··+2Λe·+Λ2e=ψ··-(ψ··d-2Λe·-Λ2e)
Using Equation (43), Equation (46) can be rewritten as (47)S·=ψ··-ψ··r

Since the uncertainty vector F~ is not considered in the dynamic equation when the equivalent control term is designed, so by substituting ψ··=M∧ψψ-1(-C∧ψψψ·-K∧Hψ+τeq) into Equation (47) and equating it to zero, the following equations can be derived: (48)M∧ψψ-1(-C∧ψψψ·-K∧Hψ+τeq)-ψ··r=0τeq=M∧ψψψ··r+C∧ψψψ·+K∧Hψ where τPID represents a PID controller. This controller is considered to improve the closed-loop stability and the transient response of the system and can be defined as (49)τPID=-M∧ψψKaS where Ka is a diagonal positive-definite constant matrix.

The adaptive term τp is considered to adapt the parameter uncertainties and disturbances. It is designed based on the estimated F~est as (Zeinali and Notash, 2010) (50)τp=-M∧ψψ(F~est) wherein F~est is the estimated vector of the parameters uncertainties and external disturbances, F~. By an online adaptation law which will be defined later, there is no need to know the bounds of parameter uncertainties. By substituting Equations (45), (46) and (50) in Equation (45) the control law (45) can be rewritten as (51)τ(t)=M∧ψψ(ψ··r-KaS-F~est)+C∧ψψψ·+K∧Hψ

In order to prove the stability of the proposed control scheme, the following Lyapunov function is considered (52)V=12(STS+EeTΓ-1Ee) where Γ is a diagonal positive-definite constant matrix and Ee is the error vector of difference between unknown uncertainties vector, F~, and its estimated vector, F~est: (53)Ee=F~est-F~
The time derivative of the Lyapunov candidate (52) is (54)V·=STS·+EeTΓ-1E·e
Using Equations (47) and (53), Equation (54) can be rewritten as (55)V·=ST(ψ··-ψ··r)+EeTΓ-1(~·Fest-~·F)
Substituting Equation (40) into Equation (55) yields (56)V·=ST(M∧ψψ-1(-C∧ψψψ·-K∧Hψ+τ)+F~-ψ··r) +EeTΓ-1(~·Fest-~·F)
Using Equations (51) and (53), Equation (56) will be (57)V·=-STKaS-STEe+EeTΓ-1(~·Fest-~·F)
By choosing the following update law (58)~·Fest=ΓS then Equation (57) can be converted into (59)V·=-STKaS-EeTΓ-1~·F
For the slow subsystem described in the previous section with slowly time-varying uncertainties, ~·F is negligible, so Equation (59) can be reduced to (60)V·=-STKaS≤0

The Lyapunov candidate and its time derivative, Equations (52) and (60), guarantee that the trajectory will asymptotically converge to surface S=0 and ensure the robust stability of the closed-loop system. The convergence problem where V·=0 can be addressed using Barbalat’s lemma (Slotine and Li, 1991; Canudas et al., 1997; Zeinali and Notash, 2010). Equations (52) and (60) clearly show that S∈L2∩L∞, Ee∈L∞ and then the control input is bounded. It follows that S·∈L∞. Then S is uniformly continuous and since S∈L∞, it can be concluded that S converges asymptotically to zero (Canudas et al., 1997).

sec.title: 3.3. Controller system design for the fast subsystem
sec.p: For designing a control law for the fast subsystem using the Lyapunov approach, the following Lyapunov candidate is determined. (61)VLyapunovf=12q·fTHqq-1q·f+12qfTKqqqf +12KqqfTKpeeaKpeeaTqf where Kq is a positive-definite matrix. The time derivative of the Lyapunov function will be (62)V·Lyapunovf=q·fTHqq-1q··f+12q·fTH·qq-1q·f+q·fTKqqqf+Kqq·fTKpeeaKpeeaTqf

By substituting Hqq-1q··f from Equation (37) and knowing the fact that H·qq-1=0, as the slow variables are considered constant in the fast time scale, Equation (62) can be expressed as (63)V·Lyapunovf=-q·fT(Hqq-1HqψCψq+Cqq)q·f-q·fTKpeeava +Kqq·fTKpeeaKpeeaTqf

Now the voltage applying to the piezoelectric actuators is designed as (64)va=-Kdv·s-KPvs where Kd and KP are two positive-definite matrices. Substituting Equation (64) in (63), and using Equation (20), we have (65)V·Lyapunovf=-q·fT(Hqq-1HqψCψq+Cqq)q·f +q·fTKpeea(KdKpe-1KpeesTq·f+KPKpe-1KpeesTqf) +Kqq·fTKpeeaKpeeaTqf
Using Equations (28) and (31), Equation (65) can be rewritten as (66)V·Lyapunovf=-q·fT(Hqq-1HqψCψq+Cqq)q·f -Kdμq·fTKpeeaKpeeaTq·f-KPμq·fTKpeeaKpeeaTqf +Kqq·fTKpeeaKpeeaTqf
If (KPμ)=Kq, then the last two terms in Equation (66) will be omitted, thus (67)V·Lyapunovf=-q·fT(Hqq-1HqψCψq+Cqq)q·f -Kdμq·fTKpeeaKpeeaTq·f

Here the second term is a negative term and Kd is defined such that Kdμ components are of order 1/ɛ. Using Equation (32) and noting the Equation (65), the above equation can be written as (68)V·Lyapunovf=-ɛ4z·fTK¯qq-1(Hqq-1HqψCψq+Cqq)K¯qq-1z·f -ɛ3z·fTK¯qq-1KpeeaKpeeaTK¯qq-1z·f

Since the velocities of the slow subsystem, due to two time scale separation, are assumed to be small; therefore, the matrices Cψq and Cqq, the matrices of the Coriolis and centrifugal effects, are of the order of or smaller than the other matrices present in Equation (68) (Slotine and Li, 1991). The other matrices are of H and K types and are assumed to be of the same order (the gain matrices are set by the control designer). Having ɛ4 (ɛ is a very small number) in the first term of that equation and ɛ3 in the second term will now justify ignoring the first term when compared with the second. Therefore, the derivative of the Lyapunov function is shown to be negative and the stability of the fast subsystem with the proposed controller is guaranteed using LaSalle’s invariant set theorem (Canudas et al., 1997).

sec.title: 4. Simulation results and discussion
sec.p: In this section the results of the numerical simulations are presented in order to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed hybrid controller scheme.

The properties and parameters of the appendages and piezoelectric layers used in this study are given in Table 1. From the simulation results of the appendage vibration while using various numbers of mode shapes, using three mode shapes is found out to be sufficient to show bending modes behavior. The initial conditions are assumed to be ψ(0)=2∘, ψ·(0)=0rad/s and q=[-0.52.200.5-2.20]T. A path with constant acceleration and deceleration at start and finish, respectively, and constant speed in the middle is considered desirable for satellite maneuver. Table 1.
The characteristics of the piezoelectric layers and the flexible appendages
Piezoelectric layer Flexible appendage
Modulus, Ep=2×109N/m2 Modulus, E=76×109N/m2
Piezoelectric constant, dp=22×10-12mV-1 Length, L=5m
Thickness, tp=1mm Thickness, ta=8mm
Width, b=0.5m Width, b=0.5m
Density, ρp=1800kg/m3 Density, ρ=2840kg/m3
Reproduced with kind permission from Elsevier (Azadi et al., 2011).
The controller parameters are considered as Kp = diag[500 580 580 500 580 580], Kd = diag[350 370 460 350 370 460] and Ka = 500, Γ=100, Λ=250.

In each appendage, three piezoelectric layers are considered as actuators and three as sensors. The appendages have the same behavior in the maneuver. Therefore, only one appendage response will be shown.

In the simulation process, governing equations of motion of the system, Equation (20), are considered and the decomposed equations of motion using singular perturbation theory are used only for hybrid control design. A parameter uncertainty of 15% of the actual values is considered and it is applied to all simulation runs. The desired and actual trajectory of the rotational maneuver around the z1-axis is shown in Figure 2. To show the capability of the controller, the initial angles are considered to be different from the desired ones. We can see from this figure that, although the initial conditions are different from the desired ones, after a short time the desired angle is well tracked and afterwards the actual angle stayed on the trajectory. For measuring the robustness of the controller against external disturbances the Td=0.15sin(100πt)τ is considered as a vector of disturbances. Figure 3 shows the desired and actual trajectory of the satellite maneuver when the vector of external disturbances is applied to the system. This figure illustrates that the adaptive sliding mode controller is robust against disturbances, so the following results are for status that the external disturbances are applied to the system. In order to demonstrate the capability and usefulness of the piezoelectric actuators, two cases are simulated. First, we consider the case when the controller is used and the voltages are applied to the piezoelectric actuators. Second, to highlight the effects of the piezoelectric layers, the satellite is equipped with a closed-loop central system to track the desired trajectory; but this time, without applying the voltages to the piezoelectric actuators. Figures 4–6 show the time histories of three generalized coordinates of the appendage. The tip deflection of the appendage is shown in Figure 7. From this figure good reliable and suitable performance of the piezoelectric actuators in suppressing the adverse vibration of the system can be seen. Figures 8–10 show the output voltages of the sensors of the appendage and Figure 11 shows the voltages applied to piezoelectric actuators bonded to the appendage. According to this figure the applied voltages to the piezoelectric actuators are in the permissible range (Li and Bainum, 1994). Figure 2.
Trajectory tracking of the angle of rotation of the satellite.
Figure 3.
Trajectory tracking of the angle of rotation of the satellite in the presence of disturbance.
Figure 4.
Time history of the first generalized coordinate of the appendage: (a) whole domain and (b) magnified from t = 0 to 0.5 s.
Figure 5.
Time history of the second generalized coordinate of the appendage: (a) whole domain and (b) magnified from t = 0 to 0.5 s. Figure 6.
Time history of the third generalized coordinate of the appendage: (a) whole domain and (b) magnified from t = 0 to 0.5 s.
Figure 7.
Tip deflection of the appendage: (a) whole domain and (b) magnified from t = 0 to 0.5 s.
Figure 8.
Output voltage of the first PZT sensor bonded to the appendage: (a) whole domain and (b) magnified from t = 0 to 0.5 s.
Figure 9.
Output voltage of the second PZT sensor bonded to the appendage: (a) whole domain and (b) magnified from t = 0 to 0.5 s. Figure 10.
Output voltage of the third PZT sensor bonded to the appendage: (a) whole domain and (b) magnified from t = 0 to 0.5 s.
Figure 11.
Applied voltage to the PZT actuators bonded to the appendage: (a) first actuator, (b) second actuator and (c) third actuator.
These figures illustrate the performance of the hybrid adaptive sliding mode/Lyapunov controller that is applied to the flexible satellite moving in an orbit.

sec.title: 5. Conclusion
sec.p: A hybrid control based on adaptive sliding mode and Lyapunov-based control proposed for the large-angle orbiting maneuver control and vibration reduction of a flexible satellite, respectively. Each satellite appendage was considered as an Euler–Bernoulli beam having large deflection. Six pairs of the piezoelectric layers have been used as sensors and actuators to suppress the appendage vibrations. The governing equations of motion were derived based on the Lagrange method and using Rayleigh–Ritz technique. Owing to the high flexibility of the appendages and large-angle maneuvers, the governing equations of motion were coupled and quite complicated. In order to apply the controller, the governing equations of the system were decomposed into slow and fast subsystems using singular perturbation theory. Then, an adaptive sliding mode control for slow and a Lyapunov-based controller for the fast subsystems were proposed and developed. The fast and slow subsystems were used only for applying the controller, and in order to simulate the response of the system the general coupled equations of motion were used. Finally, the system was simulated with considering the external disturbances and the outcomes confirmed the advantages and robustness of the hybrid control scheme.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
